name: Robert De Niro
religion: De Niro was raised by a former Catholic and an atheist and his grandparents had him secretly baptized into the Catholic Church. He now seems to be agnostic at least, perhaps even atheist.
politicalViews: De Niro is a long-time, devoted supporter of the Democratic Party.
author: Tom Kershaw

content.text: Robert De Niro was born and raised in Manhattan, New York.

content.sourceTitle: The religion of Robert De Niro, actor
content.text: De Niro's father was raised a Catholic, but when little Robbie was two years old, his father announced that he was gay and his parents got a divorce. His mother was raised Presbyterian but quickly confirmed that she was an atheist upon adulthood. De Niro's parents did not want him baptized into the Catholic Church, but during their divorce, he stayed with his devoutly Catholic grandparents who had him baptized in secret.
It's safe to say that if De Niro is anything, he's a Catholic, but he doesn't seem to practice and he doesn't want to talk about it.

De Niro is a private man. He doesn't like to be interviewed and on the rare occasions that he does grant an interview, reporters are given a list of off-limit topics, which includes religion, politics, his family, or wine (which he apparently loves).

Still, De Niro has played a disproportionate amount of Catholic characters in his movies, likely due to his association with devout Catholic director Martin Scorsese. De Niro once even played a Catholic priest in the film , which was hailed by Catholics as an honest and complimentary portrayal of a man of the cloth. But he didn't want to play Jesus in Scorsese's , saying:

content.sourceTitle: The religion of Robert De Niro, actor
content.text: was something I was never interested in doing. But I did tell [Scorsese], 'If you really have a problem, if you really want to do it, and you need me, I'll do it. If you're against the wall and have no other way, I'll do it as a friend.
Eventually, Scorsese got Willem Dafoe to play Christ, but it did bring up questions as to De Niro's true feelings about religion. Does he possibly find it objectionable. He did once say:
If there is a God he has a lot to answer for.

So it's reasonable to assume that first, De Niro questions the existence of God and second, he questions the omni-benevolence of God. I'm going to call him an agnostic, though he might be full-blown atheist.
Is there an Italian Party?

content.sourceTitle: Italy to Robert De Niro: You're Family
content.text: De Niro has been granted honorary Italian citizenship,
so his loyalties don't only lie in U.S. politics. Though he's not known to get involved in Italian or EU politics.

content.sourceTitle: Robert DeNiro's Federal Campaign Contribution Report
content.text: He has been known to get heavily involved in U.S. politics, however, and when he does it is only for the Democratic Party. In his lifetime, De Niro has donated over $70,000 to the Democratic Party.

But that's not all. De Niro campaigns for his favorite candidates. He's officially endorsed Al Gore in 2000, John Kerry in 2004, and Obama in 2008. During the Clinton "Monicagate" scandal, De Niro even lobbied Congress to not impeach the president.
In 2008, De Niro spoke at an Obama rally, saying:

content.sourceTitle: You talkin' to me? Donald Trump picks fight with Robert De Niro
content.text: I've never made a speech like this at a political event before. So, what am I doing here? Finally, one person has inspired me. Guess who.
Obama, that's who!

Still an Obama supporter in 2012, De Niro got himself into a little hot water and was called a racist by Republican presidential candidates–particularly Newt Gingrich–when he said at an Obama fundraiser:

content.sourceTitle: De Niro apologizes for joke about 'white first lady.'
content.text: Callista Gingrich, Karen Santorum, Ann Romney. Now do you really think our country is ready for a white first lady?
Can someone tell me what that even means?
